title: Heinz Sokolowski
text:
Heinz Sokolowski (17 December 1917 – 25 November 1965) was a German man who became the <a href="list%20of%20deaths%20at%20the%20Berlin%20Wall">sixty-fourth known person to die</a> at the <a href="Berlin%20Wall">Berlin Wall</a>. Sokolowski, a former <a href="political%20prisoner">political prisoner</a>, was shot and killed by <a href="East%20Germany">East German border troops</a> while attempting to cross the Berlin Wall near to the <a href="Brandenburg%20Gate">Brandenburg Gate</a> and the <a href="Reichstag%20%28building%29">Reichstag</a> building.
Life.
Heinz Sokolowski was born on 17 December 1917, in <a href="Frankfurt%20an%20der%20Oder">Frankfurt an der Oder</a>, <a href="Imperial%20Germany">Imperial Germany</a>, during the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>. Following <a href="primary%20school">primary school</a>, he apprenticed as a <a href="tailor">tailor</a> before attending a <a href="trade%20school">trade school</a> where he completed his education, eventually becoming a <a href="journalist">journalist</a> with the Frankfurt Oder Zeitung. During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Sokolowski was drafted into the <a href="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a>, fighting in various places and was also used as a <a href="war%20correspondent">war correspondent</a>, before being captured by the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> in Russia during the <a href="German%20invasion%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">German invasion of the Soviet Union</a>. Sokolowski became a <a href="prisoner%20of%20war">prisoner of war</a> under custody of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, and supposedly became a <a href="communist">communist</a> while participating in an working group.
In 1946, shortly after the war ended, Sokolowski was released from Soviet captivity in 1946 and moved into the <a href="Soviet%20sector%20of%20Berlin">Soviet sector of Berlin</a>, where he worked as a freelance journalist. The following year, he married and moved to <a href="Prenzlauer%20Berg">Prenzlauer Berg</a> with his wife and newborn daughter. The marriage lasted until 1951, and he worked for the Soviets until his arrest on 12 February 1953. A military tribunal found Sokolowski guilty on charges of <a href="espionage">espionage</a>, and sentenced him at first to twenty years, then to ten years, imprisonment in a <a href="labor%20camp">labor camp</a> in the Soviet Union. A few years later, the Soviets handed him over to the custody of the <a href="East%20Germany">German Democratic Republic</a> (East Germany) in 1956, during which he contracted <a href="tuberculosis">tuberculosis</a>.
Death.
On 13 February 1963, Sokolowski was released from prison and began working as an <a href="elevator%20operator">elevator operator</a> in <a href="East%20Berlin">East Berlin</a>, while also having applied to leave East Germany, but was not approved for emigration. He made contacts in <a href="West%20Berlin">West Berlin</a> in 1964, bringing him to the attention of the <a href="Stasi">Stasi</a>. After his dismissal as an elevator operator in May 1965, Sokolowski quickly began to plan his escape, which began at 5 AM on 25 November 1965. That morning, Sokolowski neared the border by Clara-Zetkin-Straße (now Dorotheenstraße) close the <a href="Brandenburg%20Gate">Brandenburg Gate</a> and the <a href="Reichstag%20%28building%29">Reichstag building</a> when an <a href="East%20German%20border%20guards">East German border guard</a> saw him and fired a warning shot, but he failed to respond. Other guards opened fire on Sokolowski, who had by this time reached the last wall topped with <a href="barbed%20wire">barbed wire</a>. Sokolowski was shot in the <a href="abdomen">abdomen</a> and died of his injuries on the way to the hospital.
Memorial.
A three-meter-high cross was erected at the corner of Ebertstraße and Scheidemannstraße on 13 August 1966 in memory of Heinz Sokolowski. Inscribed upon this cross are his dates of birth and death and the legend "Nach 7 Jahren DDR-Haft erschossen auf der Flucht". Sokolowski is also remembered with a <a href="White%20Crosses">White Cross</a> on the Reichstagufer.
